title: Airlie beach shark attack: two men injured off Queensland coast
text:
Both men are in a serious condition with lower limb injuries after they were bitten off the Whitsundays coast in Queensland

Emergency workers are responding to an emergency call that two men have been bitten by a shark near Airlie Beach, in the Queensland Whitsunday region.

The attack occurred amid a debate about shark control in Queensland and a landmark court ruling that forced the state to remove its lethal drumlines from the Great Barrier Reef marine park.

The two men, both aged in the 30s, are reportedly suffering lower limb injuries. They are being treated by paramedics at Abel Point Marina at Airlie Beach, having been brought back to shore by a boat. The extent of their injuries is not known.

Queensland Ambulance (@QldAmbulance) #Update1 - Two patients are being transported by road to a location on Proserpine Shute Harbour Road where they will meet up with the rescue helicopter. Both patients have sustained serious lower limb injuries and are in a serious condition.

It is unclear yet whether the attack occurred at a specific location where drumlines would have otherwise been used. Conservationists say there is no scientific evidence lethal baits prevent shark attacks.

Several people were injured – and a Victorian man killed – in a series of shark attacks in the Whitsundays last summer.

More to come.
